pros: PCI should be a great organization. It has a lot of potential. The CEO is really smart and makes a genuine effort to show her employees that she cares about them.
cons: In reality, PCI is suffering as an organization and it really comes down to a senior management team (especially in programs) that is fatally detached from the work of their employees. PCI has had rounds of lay-offs every fiscal year for some time now, and employees pay the consequences of the lack of good decision making in leadership. They talk a lot about how the organization needs to change to reflect shifting realities in the international development world, but have yet to enact any meaningful change. Many NGO reviews on Glassdoor will say that organizations lack "room for growth" - this is not only true anecdotally, but institutionally at PCI, as promotion freezes are endemic to their HR policies. Perhaps due to PCI's two HQ offices being on opposite sides of the country, internal communication is terrible (to the point where communication between DC and San Diego becomes antagonistic). Common processes are often either bottle-necked or require review/approval from an excessive amount of staff, making everyday tasks difficult to complete. As PCI continues to lose employees, management forces extra responsibilities upon those who remain rather than rehire critical staff. I do not exaggerate when I say most of my contacts in both offices are currently looking/applying for jobs elsewhere.

pros: good salary, good working environment, learning new things on the job
cons: Limited time alloted for general staff meeting

review_title: Great organization, flaws in local management
pros:
-Freedom to do your job at your pace as long as it gets done in a realistic time period.
-High organizational capacity for local benefactor (i.e. primary school students, teachers, subsistence farmers, etc.) livelihood improvement.
-Most staff care about the work they are doing and that they are having a positive/beneficial impact on their beneficiaries.
cons: Some management and certain few employees are not as invested in the goals of the organization as most.  It is a well paying job for most host country nationals in the third world (Tanzania specifically) and this salary, rather than development goals, can be the primary motivation for some.  Few members of the higher management also tend to be disconnected to what is happening on the ground and oversight is often minimal.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros:
Interesting, meaningful work that makes a difference
Headquarters San Diego has a great office culture
Friendly, caring people woirk here.
Great benefits package.
Flexible work hours
Supportive leadership
Collaborative, supportive environment.
Many positions have opportunities for travel.
cons:
No place is perfect, but there are not a lot of cons to working at PCI.
Field-based positions may have different experiences than headquarters. It varies geographically.
Some country locations are genuinely strenuous/ difficult places to work in. 
As a non-profit, the salaries at PCI are generally not as competitive as private sector (but the other benefits are really GREAT!  It also means that those who work here are in it because they love it and not for the money, and I believe this in turn positively influences the culture).

job_title: Development Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: Great work atmosphere, leadership and peers encourage you to perform and advance. Lots of benefits from human resources perspective. Excellent vacation, sick, and health coverage. Very passionate organization. Working in 16 different countries with organizational excellence and making real and lasting change as high priorities.
cons: Large organization working with minimal staff. Much needed increases in support staff to support extremely heavy work loads.

pros: Great mission & vision..doing important community based health and development work
cons: Out of date business model based primarily on USG funding therefore funding is very unstable.

review_title: Not great. Would skip on this opportunity if you're a young professional looking for cultivating work.
pros: Some of the staff members are great. They're incredibly kind, will say hello to you everyday, and greet you with a smile. The actual office space isn't horrible either, albeit a bit small and outdated. The CEO, Carrie, is awesome.
cons: This organization lacks a HUGE amount of growth. It's extremely top heavy and the "leadership", as known as the executive team, is a joke. They are all passive "leaders" and will not mentor you to success like true leaders would.  This workplace is also not that diverse - perhaps 10% of their employees are minorities. The lower level jobs have a high turnover rate because there is always fear that people will lose their jobs. Since this is a USG funded organization, there are yearly budget cuts that determine whether or not your job is still secure end of year. Employee morale is low and office employees have cliques, depending on status. In addition, a huge problem of the organization is a lack of harmonious collaboration and communication. Teams do not communicate with each other and when they do, there is rigidity in change. Any mishaps are met with passive aggression and then leadership then wonders why employees are so unmotivated and unincentivized. Overall, I would not recommend working here, especially if you have a lot of drive and passion for non-profits. Working here will demolish that passion. Also, the pay here isn't great, but that's to be expected of a non-profit—the executive team will have the largest cuts.

review_title: Excellent work culture and growth possibilities
